results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Solarchrome
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Solarchrome

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows rural Victoria footage around Omeo. It features excavation of, and images of, the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme including power station interiors and exteriors and dam footage. Also included are hobby farm images, of children and adults with calves and chickens and pet dogs and cats. There is footage of a man collecting cow manure from paddocks.

We see images of the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with goats, horses, Ayrshire and Illawarra cattle, jinkers, floats, horse-drawn carts with advertising. There is also footage of children playing childhood games on the family farm – wheelbarrow races, chasey, ball games and piggy-backs.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan):

00:00:01:00 children feeding chickens on farm
00:00:11:00 child sitting on cow and falling off as cow stands
00:00:30:00 family and friends with farm animals
00:00:48:00 man working on farm with shovel collecting cow manure
00:00:59:00 two children with kitten fighting over who gets to hold it
00:01:15:00 children playing chasing, running games around trees in rural setting
00:01:26:00 children with grandmother playing with skipping rope in rural setting (good family images and fashion example)
00:01:35:00 family on ship with crew working in background
00:02:11:00 Maroondah Dam plaque with reservoir details
00:02:46:00 men and children playing piggy back, wheelbarrow races, ball games on rural property (ood footage of childhood games and playing)
00:03:15:00 child and woman on farm with calves (good rural footage and fashion example)
00:05:11:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade including Ayrshire and Illawara cattle and goats
00:05:17:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with Jinkers, horses and carts, floats and advertising carts
00:08:19:00 Carnation Milk factory interior and exterior
00:08:57:00 Mount Beauty postal address plaque
00:10:01:00 rural footage of Kiewa Hydroelectric scheme, including images of interior and exterior power station, electricity poles and dam
00:10:33:00 road sign with vintage car in background: road sign indicating Upper Kiewa Valley Road; Mt Beauty; Rocky Valley; Howmans Gap

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1974
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This films shows time with First Nations people of New Guinea, a wedding in Goroka, a wedding in Sydney, and a royal visit of Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne to Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:19:00 ancestral house of worship – “House of Tambaran” – seems to be specific to East Sepik group in PNG
00:00:36:00 children in traditional local dress with elders, gathered and building houses
00:01:07:00 playing wooden instruments, similar to flute and pipes
00:01:30:00 stunning views of mountain scene
00:02:20:00 driving through Australian bush, then Sydney beaches
00:07:48:00 toddler in wading pool in yard, Goroka
00:10:04:00 wedding in Goroka
00:12:24:00 carnival or fair, possibly the Sydney Royal Easter Show
00:13:17:00 footage of Sydney Opera House, Circular Quay and a ferry cruise on the Sydney Harbour
00:14:55:00 views of Bondi or Bronte
00:15:38:00 friends gather in Sydney for a wedding
00:16:31:00 back to PNG, family and friends
00:17:42:00 gathering in town in traditional dress to welcome Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne
00:19:49:00 Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Princess Anne, Captain Phillip, Barry Holloway MP in back of truck being driven through crowds of people, Goroka

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows Sydney street, harbour and beach scenes and a family holiday to Tasmania and New Zealand. There are scenes of Bondi Beach, Taronga Zoo and wild animals in captivity showing a monkey riding a bicycle and performing tricks with a trainer. There are scenes on board and farewelling a passenger liner and passenger steam ferries in Sydney Harbour.

There are street scenes around Hobart, including Wrest Point Hotel, and a road trip to Mount Wellington, showing views along the way. The film shows New Zealand port towns and ports as well as a tourist boat trip on the fjords and scenery at Milford Sound. The family visits Rotorua and a recreation of a Maori Village depicting traditional Maori dance and dress performed for tourists. There are also scenes on a cruise ship of recreational activities.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:00:00 Bondi Beach scene panorama showing beach and bathers
00:00:21:00 Sydney/Bondi street scenes showing cars, pedestrians and double decker bus
00:00:34:00 Taronga Zoo showing caged monkeys, birds, camels, zebra, impala, giraffes
00:01:15:00 horses, dogs and monkeys in costumes riding bicycles, doing tricks with trainer
00:01:56:00 farewelling a passenger liner with streamers at Sydney Harbour
00:02:21:00 crowded Sydney steam ferry at Sydney Harbour
00:02:51:00 Wrest Point Hotel, “Portlight Bar” sign with street and water scenes showing cars and pedestrians
00:03:11:00 Tasmanian Road sign indicating direction and distance to Tasman Highway, Lindisfarne, Cambridge Aerodrome, Bellerive
00:03:31:00 family group facing camera at lookout point on Mount Wellington (good fashion reference)
00:03:50:00 people on Mount Wellington look-out point taking photos with camera mounted on wooden tripod
00:03:59:00 Milford Sound tourist boat trip footage showing fjord and surrounding mountains, waterfalls, light planes flying, tourists on boat
00:05:25:00 New Zealand Port Town – possibly Wellington, showing rooftops and harbour
00:05:32:00 Wellington Cable Car, New Zealand
00:05:34:00 signage for Wellington Council Cable Car and entrance to Botanical Gardens
00:05:42:00 car driving along winding road above Wellington Harbour, driver waves out of the window
00:06:00:00 New Zealand street scenes showing buildings, pedestrians and cars
00:06:12:00 Orsova passenger ship in New Zealand port
00:06:29:00 ships, ferry and rower in a New Zealand port
00:06:43:00 Frankton Train Station sign
00:07:04:00 sign on side of building for Princes Gate Hotel. Tourist House License.
00:07:05:00 Waiariki Wai-Ora baths, showing bathers, signage and bathers around the pool
00:07:12:00 Maori women performing traditional dance for tourists in a recreation of a village
00:07:33:00 tourist women and children pose with Maori women dressed in traditional dress
00:07:38:00 male tourist and children pose with Maori women dressed in traditional dress
00:07:42:00 tourist women interact with Maori man dressed in traditional dress
00:07:45:00 Rotorua hot mud pools and geysers with tourists
00:07:57:00 children in wooden hot tubs at Rotorua
00:07:59:00 saucepans and kettles in hot tubs steaming over hot springs
00:08:01:00 tourist women and children posing with Maori woman and child as tourist attraction
00:08:05:00 close-up of Maori woman and child in traditional dress in tourist village
00:08:07:00 tourists wave from Kia Mau Mahara Bridge
00:08:14:00 tourists standing in front of N.Z. R. Road Services bus
00:08:33:00 people playing quoits on board a passenger ship with people in deckchairs and ocean in the background
00:08:38:00 people swimming in a pool on board a passenger liner with deckchairs in the background
00:08:46:00 woman on board ship sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
00:08:49:00 older woman on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
00:08:50 young boy on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
00:08:52:00 man on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck

00:08:33:00 people playing quoits on board a passenger ship with people in deckchairs and ocean in the background
00:08:38:00 people swimming in a pool on board a passenger liner with deckchairs in the background
00:08:46:00 woman on board ship sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
00:08:49:00 older woman on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
00:08:50 young boy on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
00:08:52:00 man on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck
description_for_label:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows Sydney street, harbour and beach scenes and a family holiday to Tasmania and New Zealand. There are scenes of Bondi Beach, Taronga Zoo and wild animals in captivity showing a monkey riding a bicycle and performing tricks with a trainer. There are scenes on board and farewelling a passenger liner and passenger steam ferries in Sydney Harbour.

There are street scenes around Hobart, including Wrest Point Hotel, and a road trip to Mount Wellington, showing views along the way. The film shows New Zealand port towns and ports as well as a tourist boat trip on the fjords and scenery at Milford Sound. The family visits Rotorua and a recreation of a Maori Village depicting traditional Maori dance and dress performed for tourists. There are also scenes on a cruise ship of recreational activities.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:00:00 Bondi Beach scene panorama showing beach and bathers
00:00:21:00 Sydney/Bondi street scenes showing cars, pedestrians and double decker bus
00:00:34:00 Taronga Zoo showing caged monkeys, birds, camels, zebra, impala, giraffes
00:01:15:00 horses, dogs and monkeys in costumes riding bicycles, doing tricks with trainer
00:01:56:00 farewelling a passenger liner with streamers at Sydney Harbour
00:02:21:00 crowded Sydney steam ferry at Sydney Harbour
00:02:51:00 Wrest Point Hotel, “Portlight Bar” sign with street and water scenes showing cars and pedestrians
00:03:11:00 Tasmanian Road sign indicating direction and distance to Tasman Highway, Lindisfarne, Cambridge Aerodrome, Bellerive
00:03:31:00 family group facing camera at lookout point on Mount Wellington (good fashion reference)
00:03:50:00 people on Mount Wellington look-out point taking photos with camera mounted on wooden tripod
00:03:59:00 Milford Sound tourist boat trip footage showing fjord and surrounding mountains, waterfalls, light planes flying, tourists on boat
00:05:25:00 New Zealand Port Town – possibly Wellington, showing rooftops and harbour
00:05:32:00 Wellington Cable Car, New Zealand
00:05:34:00 signage for Wellington Council Cable Car and entrance to Botanical Gardens
00:05:42:00 car driving along winding road above Wellington Harbour, driver waves out of the window
00:06:00:00 New Zealand street scenes showing buildings, pedestrians and cars
00:06:12:00 Orsova passenger ship in New Zealand port
00:06:29:00 ships, ferry and rower in a New Zealand port
00:06:43:00 Frankton Train Station sign
00:07:04:00 sign on side of building for Princes Gate Hotel. Tourist House License.
00:07:05:00 Waiariki Wai-Ora baths, showing bathers, signage and bathers around the pool
00:07:12:00 Maori women performing traditional dance for tourists in a recreation of a village
00:07:33:00 tourist women and children pose with Maori women dressed in traditional dress
00:07:38:00 male tourist and children pose with Maori women dressed in traditional dress
00:07:42:00 tourist women interact with Maori man dressed in traditional dress
00:07:45:00 Rotorua hot mud pools and geysers with tourists
00:07:57:00 children in wooden hot tubs at Rotorua
00:07:59:00 saucepans and kettles in hot tubs steaming over hot springs
00:08:01:00 tourist women and children posing with Maori woman and child as tourist attraction
00:08:05:00 close-up of Maori woman and child in traditional dress in tourist village
00:08:07:00 tourists wave from Kia Mau Mahara Bridge

00:08:33:00 people playing quoits on board a passenger ship with people in deckchairs and ocean in the background

00:08:49:00 older woman on board passenger liner sitting in deck chair posing with Orsova London Life Saving ring around her neck

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This very short film contains footage of mountains on the way to Lae, New Guinea. It relates to reel B2003518.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 side of the car says ‘I like Swipe’: may refer to “Swipe” cleaning products
00:00:18:00 stunning views of mountains
00:01:06:00 war memorial or monument

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:02:47:00 changing of the Guard
00:05:23:00 Stonehenge – brief look at Stonehenge
00:05:34:00 Stratford-Upon-Avon Cricket Club sign, walking through gardens and a spot of cricket
00:06:58:00 Shakespeare’s Birthplace Trust
00:09:17:00 road trip sign to Penrith, Carlisle and Kendal
00:10:17:00 Fferry trip – Windemere ferry, ’The Ferry House Windemere Laboratory of the Freshwater Biological Association Private Gardens’
00:13:15:00 Loch Lomond Sailings Ltd
00:14:42:00 the Elizabethan Inn – filmmaker and wife meet up with three other women at the inn
00:15:39:00 Tormore Distillery with friends – Long John Scotch Whiskey
00:16:56:00 father and two young girls feeding ducks at a lake
00:17:41:00 Roths Glen Hotel – mini donkeys and friends
00:19:11:00 sign to Pitlochry
00:19:45:00 castle or Military Fort in Edinburgh, guards in kilts
00:20:17:00 cemetery for soldier dogs
00:21:14:00 Blackpool

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 - Indigo
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Antartica, Future, Wake up Return 2 Heart, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Air Fiction (Andy Taylor), Steve Law (Zen Paradox), Tom Cia, Derek ‘Chill’ Shiel and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a family picnic in a parkland or bush, featuring a 1950s style car. The family pose for the camera, smile and wave. The film is a good example of picnicking and fashion of the period.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a family picnic beside a 1950s style car in a bush or parkland setting
00:00:26:00 great shot of a young boy grimacing with effort as he pops open a bottle with a utensil
00:00:39:00 close-up of a woman holding a baby
00:01:07:00 a man and woman hug surrounded by trees
00:01:13:00 the family exit the car in the driveway of a brick house, waving and smiling at the camera; the house features a large striped awning over the window

results.title: On a Sunday he went fishing
results.creator_credit: Sarah Mifsud, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

video_links.name: On a Sunday he went fishing

results.brief_description: Sarah Mifsud’s father was an avid fisherman as was his father before him. Mifsud tells of the ordinary Sunday which turned tragically extraordinary for her family and the journey to rebuild in the aftermath.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sarah Mifsud, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Egami
results.creator_credit: Sue Ford and Victorian Women's Film Unit
results.brief_description: In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Melbourne landmarks are totalitarian monuments, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

constellations_primary.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Sue Ford and Victorian Women’s Film Unit
results.description: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
description_for_label: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
